summary: This is an academic research article titled 'To Tell or Not to Tell' published in the journal Violence Against Women. It presents a study on the patterns of rape disclosure among women, finding that 24% of participants had never disclosed their assault, and explores factors related to non-disclosure, self-blame, and mental health outcomes. The document is part of the Epstein case files but appears to be background research material on victim psychology rather than a direct case document. This document is an academic research article titled 'Violence Against Women' analyzing a study of 242 female rape survivors. It examines demographic characteristics, disclosure patterns, help-seeking behaviors, mental health outcomes, and factors like self-blame between first-time disclosers and those who had disclosed previously. The study finds no significant difference in PTSD rates between groups but identifies self-blame as a major factor for non-disclosers. This document is an academic article from the journal 'Violence Against Women' discussing the challenges of disclosure for sexual assault victims and recommending counseling strategies and online interventions. It is a literature review and research article, not a direct case document about Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Carrie M. Carretta
persons.context: Corresponding author of the research article, affiliated with Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. She is the principal investigator of the study on rape disclosure.

persons.name: Ann W. Burgess
persons.context: Listed as an author of the academic article, affiliated with Boston College and has a private psychiatric nursing practice.

events.title: Smith et al. study on delayed disclosure
events.description: Early published evidence indicated restricted disclosure of rape; 28% of child rape victims had never told anyone prior to the research interview.

events.title: Fisher et al. study on rape reporting factors
events.description: Research identified key factors that contributed to rape reporting, including self-blame, seriousness, victim-offender relationships, and victim characteristics.

events.title: Starzynski et al. study on disclosure decisions
events.description: Research emphasized that deciding whom to tell about sexual assault is an important and potentially consequential decision for survivors.

events.title: FBI rape statistics
events.description: 90,427 incidents of rape reported to law enforcement resulted in only 23,307 arrests (25.8% of reported cases).

events.title: Wolitzky-Taylor et al. college women study
events.description: Interviewed a national sample of 2,000 college women; only 11.5% reported their most recent/only rape experience to authorities.

events.title: Orchowski and Gidycz prospective study
events.description: Examined predictors of sexual assault disclosure, finding women most often disclosed to a female peer.

keyFacts: The study found that 24% of the 242 women in the sample had never disclosed their rape to anyone prior to the survey.
Almost two thirds (approx. 66%) of non-disclosing women believed the abuse was their fault, compared to 39.1% of women who had previously disclosed.
Non-disclosing women were significantly less likely to seek treatment for emotional injuries compared to those who had disclosed.
The majority of respondents endorsed support for online counseling over telephone or individual contact.
The document cites FBI clearance rates for rape averaging about 50% per year, and that the vast majority of rapists are never brought to justice.
The study analyzed 242 female rape survivors, finding 24% had never disclosed their assault until participating in the survey.

A major finding was that 63.8% of first-time disclosers believed the abuse was their fault, compared to 39.1% of prior disclosers, identifying self-blame as a key diagnostic factor for non-disclosure.
There were no statistically significant differences in PTSD rates, depression, or anxiety between first-time disclosers and those who had disclosed previously.
Only 24.5% of the sample reported the rape to police, and treatment-seeking for emotional injuries was low, especially among first-time disclosers.
The study suggests that disclosure itself is not cathartic enough for symptom remission and highlights self-blame, secrecy, and non-disclosure as self-protective mechanisms that hinder recovery.
The document is an academic article focused on disclosure challenges and counseling for sexual assault victims, not a primary source document related to the Epstein case.
It recommends specific counseling steps for helping victims with disclosure decisions, including predicting reactions and weighing pros/cons.
The article advocates for online/web-based interventions as a preferred and effective method for reaching survivors, especially in underserved areas.
It cites numerous academic studies on sexual violence, mental health, and treatment modalities from 2000-2013.
The authors declare no conflicts of interest and received no financial support for the research.
